reviewText: THE AVIATOR is Martin Scorsese's and Leonardo DiCaprio's absolutely gorgeous period piece highlighting the peak of eccentric billionaire Howard Hughes' life through the late 1920s into the late 1940s.Scorsese truly needs to reevaluate his filmmaking. While uniformly well-made, his recent films seem to lack direct relevance to the audience. Still, having purged themselves of the excesses of THE GANGS OF NEW YORK, Scorsese and DiCaprio do a masterful job of capturing the ambience and decadence of Hollywood's golden era. Given the egomaniacal narcissists with whom Hughes was surrounded, it's little wonder he later became a recluse. DiCaprio doesn't resemble the rough-hewn Hughes at all (despite the addition of shoe-polish black hair and a pencil-thin moustache), nor is he powerful enough as an actor to carry the role well, but he does touch the essence of the man.Hughes was a man who never did anything in a small way: In keeping with his obsessive-compulsive nature, he spent millions on what others considered mere details. His World War One flying epic HELL'S ANGELS was the longest, most complex, most expensive film shot circa 1930 (and was totally redone in the middle when Hughes decided to make it a talkie). He quested for aviation speed records (and acquired them by dint of his insistence upon having flush rivets in the fuselage of his plane, a first). He loved some of Hollywood's most amazing women (among them Katharine Hepburn and Ava Gardner). He designed a cleavage-enhancing wonder bra for Jane Russell to wear in his western THE OUTLAW (when he was told that the film would never make it past the censors, he responded rather incredulously, "Who doesn't like %!%$?"). He designed the world's largest flying boat, the behemoth-like Hercules (aka the Spruce Goose) totally out of wood (it flew once, and is now a museum display). Hughes also owned Trans-World Airlines and invented the pressurized cabin and hydraulic controls. In short, anyone who's ever been an airline passenger owes it to Howard Hughes.While DiCaprio doesn't bring all this to the fore (some of it is in the extras in the two CD set, along with much information on Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder), he does show us that, as the price for his brilliance, Hughes was a man who suffered the usual clamor of daily life in intense pain. The pop of flashbulbs, the crunch of broken glass, and the asymmetrical disorder of green peas on a dinner plate were enough to drive Hughes into a frenzy. In colloquial terms he was as crazy as a bedbug. Clinically, he suffered from OCD. Hughes had an irrational fear particularly of contamination. Because of this mental illness, Hughes descended into an isolated darkness where he handwashed till he bled, and lived in a masking-tape bordered world which represented his own fantasy-driven germ-free zone. In the end he lived in a Las Vegas suite with tinted windows and saw no one.Impressive supporting performances are given by Cate Blanchett (as a surprisingly pompous Katharine Hepburn), Kate Beckinsale (who gained twenty pounds to play the voluptuous Ava Gardner), Alec Baldwin (as Pan Am founder Juan Trippe, Hughes' chief business rival, with whom he maintained a cordial hatred), and Alan Alda (as Senator Owen Brewster). Brewster was all but owned by Trippe, and was later the ax-man for Tail Gunner Joe McCarthy. As a trenchant comment on latter-day political trends, Alda's Brewster is a pure special-interests hack, trying to drive Hughes out of business against Trippe with some specious charges of war profiteering. Hughes battles back manfully: "Free junkets down to Peru, Mr. Senator from Maine? They must be buying a lot of lobsters in Lima this year, I guess."A fine film but not a great film. THE AVIATOR definitely keeps you involved. Well worth the time.

reviewText: Here's another Oscar nominee that includes a lot of big stars acting out two-dimensional cardboard characters (Leonardo di Capiro as Howard Hughes, Cate Blanchett as Kathryn Hepburn and Kate Beckinsale as Lana Turner) in situations that may or may not have actually occurred in Hughes' tumultuous life.The exquisite sets, lighting and production values are what make this film a keeper and entertaining. Hughes' obsession with perfection and clinical cleaningless are acted out by Leonardo with some acumen but would be only half as effective without the extravagent sets and production.I was very disappointed that director Martin Scorses allowed these fine, wonderful actors -- especially the marvelous Blanchett -- to act out these famous people in such minimalist fashion. Hell, all Blanchett had to do to act like Hepburn was copy her famous accent. Wasn't there more to this fascinating woman than that? Di Caprio never really escaped into the role of Hughes even though his hairdresser did what (s)he could to dress him up like famous images of the tycoon.The very best part of this flick is a wonderful plane crash over a swanky Los Angeles neighborhood that occurs about two-thirds of the way through the film. This is a modern work of art and one of the most successful special effect driven events since Tom Hanks flight came apart when he went to that island and lived there alone.I guess this movie was entertaining overall but I watched a little bitty movie most of you never heard of the next night -- "A Slipping Down Life" -- that had none of "The Aviator"'s ambition but had two wonderful performances of people much closer to real life than the cardboard characters projected here.So don't be all your apples into high profile, big budget Hollywood extravaganzas if you are indeed interested in seeing wonderful performances on DVD or in the theater. This is a good movie but not as good as the little filck I saw the next night, in my view.
summary: Great production values are the essential ingredient

reviewText: First, whether you see "The Aviator" in the theater or do not catch it until it comes out on DVD, make a point of sticking around for the entire credits. Yes, the names of the cast members go bye way too quickly and you have to wait for a long while, but right at the end the music shifts from Howard Shore's soundtrack to the song "Howard Hughes" by Leadbelly.  It probably would have also worked if Martin Scorsese had put that at the start of the credits (and I think it might have worked), but even at the end it is a nice touch, especially when you think about what point in Hughes' life when Leadbelly would have been singing it.No more than anyone who remembers hearing the news about the strange death of Howard Hughes, Martin Scorsese's film about the man's life knows that no matter what he does his fate is going to be a bizarre figure, with uncut hair and untrimmed nails, constantly using tissues to be sure he does not touch anything.  The reason why Hughes had this obsession with cleanliness is made clear by the film's opening scene where a young Howard is bathed by his mother.  She tests his ability to spell, but more importantly she warns him of the dangers of germs.  Every time as a an adult Howard Hughes (Leonardo DiCaprio) washes his hands or becomes upset by a speck of dirt on someone's coat or become trapped in a men's room in one of the film's best sequences, we know that it is the ghost of his dead mother whispering in his ear.The problem with "The Aviator" is that while we understand why Howard Hughes is obsessed with avoiding germs we do not understand why at key moments in his life he is able to rise above his compulsion and accomplish something pretty impressive.  I do not know if we would say that Hughes ever accomplished anything great, because speed records are made to be broken and I am not sure how important countersinking rivets is in the history of aviation design (I think it would be a key innovation, but what do I know?).  However, one moment he is locked in a projection room where the floor is covered in newspapers and discarded tissues, repeating sentences and finding a different use for empty milk bottles, and the next he is going toe-to-toe with a U.S. Senator (Alan Alda) in public hearings and shaking hands with the common folk.  Apparently, if it were not for Ava Gardner (Kate Beckingsdale), Howard Hughes would have been better off dying in one those crashes that seemed to attend his flight tests of new planes.My first thought in seeing the 6' 1" DiCaprio in the role is that he is too short to play Hughes, who was 6' 4".  But in the last act of the movie DiCaprio has got the look down and you would swear he seems taller than he was in the first half of the film and have no doubt that he would be nominated for an Academy Award for his performance.  That is because this is one of the more restrained depictions of madness we have seen in recent films.  Likewise, as Katharine Hepburn, Cate Blanchett avoids caricature by suggesting the legendary actresses' signature manner of speaking rather than imitating it precisely."The Aviator" focuses on the glory days of Howard Hughes, but even though it ends with a pair of relative successes (each is more the avoidance of complete destruction and failure), the final note is a reminder that the hero is going to end up as a crazy hermit.  You can make an argument based on Scorsese's film that at best, this guy's life was a wash.  In the context of this film the tipping point is the end of his relationship with Hepburn, and while that could well be the case, I have to take exception to the portrait of her drawn by John Logan's script.Despite the indication of a wonderful scene where Hughes is subjected to a lunch at the Hepburn home, where the Connecticut Yankee family (including Hepburn's ex-husband) all gang up on their half-deaf visitor, the film argues that the problem with the relationship was that Hepburn became jealous of the publicity Hughes was receiving, especially when he was out with Bette Davis, Ginger Rogers, or some other starlet.  Since I know more about Katharine Hepburn than probably any other public figure, I have to say this just does not jive with what I know about her.  When Hughes takes her to a movie premier it does not ring true for one of the most private actresses this side of Greta Garbo.  Besides, there are plenty of other reasons for Hepburn to give up on Hughes without Spencer Tracy entering the picture.Although Scorsese once again does a stellar job of catching a by-gone era (Hughes walking a red carpet strewn with discarded flashlight bulbs while escorting Jean Harlow to the premier of "Hell's Angels" stands out), "The Aviator" really ends up being DiCaprio's movie.  He carries every big scene in the film.  Blanchett and Alda are both up for supporting Oscars for their performances, but I want to single out Alec Baldwin's as Juan Trippe, head of Pan Am.  While Alda is pulling out every mannerism in the book, Baldwin is remarkably understated and equally effective.  There was a reason this guy skipped out on the Jack Ryan franchise to do "A Streetcar Named Desire" and someday somebody is going to write Baldwin an Oscar winning role (the question is whether it will be for a lead or supporting role).
summary: This film about Hughes is more DiCaprio's than Scorsese's

reviewText: I was disappointed with this film.  I expected more.  After all, it won a lot of academy awards.  It was directed by Martin Scorcese and had lots of star power.  It also was the life story of Howard Hughes, the eccentric millionaire who built airplanes and made movies.  The trappings for a great film were all there.I just wish I could have felt some sympathy for the emotionally tortured Hughes.  As played by Leonardo Di Caprio, the character seemed a caricature. Whenever he tried to show emotion, he just crinkled his forehead.  As the film went on character aged the makeup people made that forehead crease deeper and deeper.  This just is not substitute for good acting.  Cate Blanchard did her best to act like Katherine Hepburn.  But, alas, there are too many real Katherine Hepburn movies around and we've all seen the genuine article.  Blanchard  tried hard. But there was no doubt she was only playing a role.  I have the same comment about Kate Beckensale, who tried to play the role of Ava Gardner.  Her performance just didn't work.I found the story interesting but very predictable because of course I've heard of Howard Hughes.  No money was spared for the cinematography or the sets.  And even though the film was almost three hours long, I was never bored.  I might have even liked it if it wasn't for all the hype about it. And I think it would have been a better film if it were totally fictionalized and not try so hard to be about a real person.  This is the most overrated film of the year.  And, in spite of it's reputation, I can't really recommend it.
summary: The most overrated film of the year.  I can't recommend it.

reviewText: Despite a poorly-designed DVD cover (the picture of DiCaprio looks huge and demented), this is a classic movie that would make a great addition to your DVD collection.  The story is about Howard Hughes, an aviation genius and pioneer who also suffered from a debilitating mental illness.Hughes is known widely for crazy behavior.  A humorous episode of the Simpsons spoofed Hughes. Mr. Burns, with wild hair and long nails, points a gun at Smithers and orders him to get into a tiny model plane Burns has dubbed the "Spruce Caboose."  This is a take on Hughes' famous "Spruce Goose," which is featured in the film.Howard Hughes was born in Texas in 1905.  His father invented a revolutionary mining drill bit that revolutionized drilling and kept Hughes in coattails for life, no matter how much money he spent.  Hughes was an orphan at 18, his parents dying within two years of each other.  He was a high school and college dropout, and took over his father's business.Hughes loved airplanes and movies.  His big movie, "Hell's Angels," (1930) combined both.  Using a fleet of genuine WWI planes, the movie's budget was insane for the time.  Although the film was a box office smash, he still lost over a million dollars on it.  Hughes founded Hughes Aircraft.  He proceeded to build planes and break speed and distance records.  Some called him "the second Lindbergh."Hughes also was a playboy, dating a string of beautiful actresses.  The film is almost as much about them as it is about the billionaire.  Katherine Hepburn's (Cate Blanchett) relationship with Hughes is strongly profiled.  A scene of her family at the dinner table when Hughes meets them is hilarious.  Kate Beckinsdale as Ava Gardner turns in a classy performance.With this performance, that missed a Best Actor Academy Award by a hair, DiCaprio has forever thrown off the mantle of pretty boy/Pack Rat Jr. actor.  His performance is so laudable in every way.  He has really grown up.  Blanchett overacts, unsuccessfully trying too hard to channel Hepburn.  It is like she studied the actress's mannerisms so hard, she forgot to be natural.

reviewText: The story of Howard Hughes is a lot more exciting than I expected it to be.  The film begins with the making of the lavish spectacular 'Hell's Angels' in 1930, and continues through to Hughes's battle to preserve his TWA airline after WW2.I took a great dislike to Leonardo di Caprio in 'Titanic' which I absolutely loathed. Likewise I disliked Cate Blanchett in 'Elizabeth.  Here, however, both actors give terrific performances, Cate Blanchett is marvellous as Katherine Hepburn and diCaprio carries this very long film without once boring me.  There are excellent supporting performances too, I particularly enjoyed Alan Alda as obnoxious Senator Brewster, and Jude Law is suitably gorgeous and raffish in a cameo performance as Errol Flynn.It is diCaprio's film though, and a very good film it is.

reviewText: The stars just keep popping up in this superbly directed, beautifully shot and extremely well acted bio-pic. It certainly deserved every Academy Award it received and probably several more should have been awarded. Leonardo DiCaprio provides an eerily realistic visual similarity to Howard Hughes no doubt enhanced by his stellar portrayal of the lead character. The list of actors and actresses just keeps growing as the movie progresses and each one of them steps up to the plate and hit more home-runs with their characters too. This movie is a "Must See" and without a doubt is a welcome "Blu-Ray Worthy" addition to my home movie collection. Get it, watch it, you'll love it !
summary: All star cast gives all star performance

reviewText: This Hollywood bio-pic on one of the most eccentric Americans of the 20th century proves to be quite entertaining and well done. The movie basically focus on Howard Hughes' aviation interest and his obsessive complusive behaviors. Two love interests were thrown in as well. Cate Blanchett does a wonderful job as Katharine Hepburn even although the movie does exaggerated their relationship. Kate Beckinsale played Ava Gardner who also does a pretty good job. Leonardo DiCaprio may not looked like Howard Hughes but he does managed to capture Hughes' aviation spirit and his insane genius. DiCaprio also plays Hughes' OCD mental disease with certain amount of intensity and sympathy.The movie does gross over most of Hughes' affairs with countless of other women, his other parts of his financial empire as well as most of his career as Hollywood producer although it did highlighted his involvment in Hell's Angels due to the aviation approach. It also skipped Hughes' inevitable decline and fall as a functional human being due to his mental illness even although the movie did showed the initial taste of what was to come.But overall, this proves to be a well acted, well directed and well written movie. Much of this credit goes to the director, Martin Scorsese who have proven once more that he haven't lost all his touches yet. DiCaprio proves to be quite good and he was well supported by his fellow cast members. Even Alec Baldwin who played the head of Pan American Airway and Hughes' enemy, didn't hammed up like he usually does. The movie doesn't overextend itself and managed to keep its priorities straight and focus on the main themes of the movie. Although it was nearly three hours long, it was one of those movies where you hardly felt the passage of time. In some way, you walked away from this movie feeling bit sorry for Howard Hughes; with all his money, fame and intelligence, he couldn't escape the doom that await him in the future.

reviewText: My husband and I liked this movie - except for the horrible plane crash that Hughes experienced. It was so graphic and painful that my husband was still talking about it the next day. The portrayal of OCD in Hughes life was very brilliantly played by DiCaprio and Cate Blanchett made a surprisingly accurate Katherine Hepburn.The Aviator is a movie that we have to plan to watch because it is so long and time-consuming. Usually it's a rainy day film, or one that we reserve for pizza nights when it's just the two of us. It IS a long watch. I find myself skipping ahead to some more poignant scenes at times. Overall, we like it - once in awhile.

reviewText: I had never heard about the life of Howard Hughes before, so "The Aviator" provided me with an eyeopening exposure to one of the most excentric millionaires of the past century, who ironically enough also happened to be responsible for many of the greatest advancements in commercial aviation during his lifetime.Very well acted, and packed with great talent, the movie touches it all: his titanic contributions to aviation and moviemaking; his flirting with the world's greatest divas of the first half of the 20th century; his David vs. Goliath struggle against PanAm, the world's greatest airline at the time; and his public appearance in front of Congress to redeem himself. All of it happens in the midst of Hughes' torment in dealing with his biggest enemy: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD).We certainly got to thank Scorcese for (yet another) great movie, but as you see the extra fetures, it becomes apparent that DiCaprio is to be thanked just as much if not more. The actor took it upon himself to dig deep into the life of the character, and brought to the screen a fantastically close depiction of his traits, fears and overall personality.After sitting through it, my only complaint (though minor, when compared with the epic proportions of the undertaking) is that it was too long. That aside, this is going to be a movie for the ages, and one that will hopefully create even more awareness about this psychiatric condition known as OCD.

reviewText: Director Martin Scorcese presents the life of Texan billionaire Howard Hughes, played by Leonardo DiCaprio. The film focuses on Hughes' life from the time that he appears on the public radar by shooting Hell's Angels, the most expensive movie ever made, to a short time after he has successfully test-pilots Hercules, the biggest airplane ever made.In between these two events, Hughes courted some of the most beautiful women in Hollywood (at times, seemingly, all of the most beautiful women in Hollywood), flirts with fianncial ruin, battles the insurmountable combination of big corporate rivals and government, and, most intriguingly, fights a losing battle with an increasingly severe case of Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.Scorcese uses plenty of gimmicks and conventional techniques to bring his vision to the screen, including having each section of the film appear as if it had been shot in the year that it portrays. This explains some of the odd color schemes and tints, especially early on.Early in the movie, there is an almost palpable sense of menace that hangs over Hughes. The tension as he flies through the night air with Katherine Hepburn (played by Cate Blanchette), or even walks to a premiere on a red carpet littered with broken lightbulbs is almost unbearable. There's just always a sense that some terrible event is about to occur, and it's almost a relief when the twin dangers of full blown OCD and a horrible plane crash are revealed.Scorcese and DiCaprio work overtime in this film, and they succeed in brining a multi-dimensional portrait of this complicated and tortured individual to life. The great contradiction of this character is that his wealth gives him power beyond imagining, power which allows him to indulge the most expensive and trifling of whims. However, his inner demons make him astoundingly, and painfully, vulnerable. He rules a magnificent financial empire, but crumbles when confronted with a rare steak, or an over-friendly dog. And the contradiction is even more engrossing because Hughes clearly realizes that his obsessions are not rational, and struggles to overcome the revulsion that his body experiences. Tellingly, he is most able to push his demons aside when put in a crisis situation, and he rises to the occasion when forced to appear before a congressional committee.I don't think that this will go down in history as a great movie. The fact that it nabbed so much Oscar attention is a sad comment on the state of mainstream films this year. This is a good, solid movie, but it stands out only because the bar is set so low.Personally, I don't think I'd buy this movie because, as good as it is, it doesn't bear repeat viewings. The movie's length, and the fact that it is more depressing than uplifting, make for a great trip to the theater, or a great rental, but not a great pruchase.
summary: Sadly, one of the best films of the year

reviewText: The Aviator is a brilliant film with great acting! Leonardo DiCaprio gives a very fine portrait of Howard Hughes both as a competitive genius and as a tortured soul struggling with inner demons including Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder that made him repetitively wash his hands and perform other tasks. The other actors shine, too. The special effects like what we see in the airplane crash are outstanding; the choreography is excellent as well. The cinematography reflects a great deal of forethought; director Martin Scorsese made the colors look increasingly sophisticated as the years passed to reflect how the use of color in film improved during Howard Hughes' life--this got the film an Oscar for Best Cinematography! Indeed, there's little lacking in this movie; even the musical score enhances the film greatly.When the biopic starts we briefly see Howard Hughes as a young boy being taught by his mother to be overly careful about germs and to avoid groups of people she doesn't like including African-Americans. The film flash-forwards to 1927 as Hughes struggles to create what he hopes will be an incredibly fantastic motion picture, Hell's Angels. Howard hires his right hand man Noah Dietrich (John C. Reilly) to manage his funds and operate his business on a day-to-day basis; and there's Adam Scott in the role of Johnny Meyer, who Hughes refers to as his "press agent." After quite some time (think two years plus) the movie is completed and ready for its premiere--but not before Hughes makes the film as realistic as possible by hiring scores of extras some of whom pilot made-to-order planes that really do fly; stealing meteorologist Professor Fitz (Ian Holm) from another company to make clouds that move and ultimately reshooting the entire film for sound!There's clearly much more to an epic film like this; but I won't add too much to avoid spoilers. While in real life Hughes was married to Ella Rice and Jean Peters while romancing woman including Evelyn Brent and Billie Dove, the film focuses on Howard Hughes' romantic relationships with two women: Katherine Hepburn (Cate Blanchett) in particular and Ava Gardner (Kate Beckinsale). In addition, there's Howard's love for aviation and his desire to make planes that go faster and faster (not to mention making planes that could help the United States during World War Two); his handling of TWA to make it a competitive international commercial airline; his pride at building a huge plane he called "The Hercules" and his gradually worsening mental illness which tends to flare up when Hughes is under pressure.More excellent performances include Kelli Garner as a very young Faith Domergue; Alan Alda as Senator Brewster; Alec Baldwin as Juan Trippe, the top man at Pan Am; Gwen Stefani as Jean Harlow and Jude Law as Errol Flynn.The first DVD offers an optional running commentary; but the second DVD truly has an abundance of superb bonus features to delight you. I really liked the History Channel documentary on Howard Hughes; the extra about Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder; "The Aviator and the Age of Glamour" and "An Evening with Leonardo DiCaprio and Alan Alda."The Aviator is a must-have for fans of the actors in the film. People who like biopics and dramas based on real life will not be disappointed!
summary: the portrait of a man with emotionally charged performances

reviewText: "The Aviator" is a marvelous and amazing movie. It's long at nearly three hours but is so well crafted that the time zips by. It's both a biography and a fantasy because much of its subject matter revolves around Hollywood in the 1930s and because its protagonist, Howard Hughes, was even larger than the larger than life stars he mingled with.Leonardo DiCaprio plays Hughes, the incredibly rich heir to a Texas fortune. Brash, young and emotionally unstable, he headed to Hollywood determined to make movies. He produced "Hell's Angels", which at the time was the most expensive movie ever made. Moguls laughed at his efforts, but the movie went on to become a smash hit. Meanwhile, Hughes became obsessed with aviation, founded Hughes Aircraft and later started TWA airlines.The fascinating thing about Hughes was that, while he was an intelligent and handsome man, he was bedeviled by madness. I suspect everyone around him, including Katherine Hepburn [Kate Blanchett], who was his lover, knew this. We may never know if it was just his money that kept him afloat or if there was something special about him.DiCaprio is superb. He rivals Johnny Depp as a physical actor. His intensity almost jumps off the screen. Kate Blanchett both is and isn't Hepburn, perhaps the most unique star of all time, but her portrayal is superb."The Aviator" captures a period of American history in an extraordinary way. Some have said that the movie is a little cold. I think the truth is that its subject, Mr. Hughes, was a bit unknowable.
summary: Superb retelling of the Howard Hughes story

reviewText: Martin Scorsese delivers his best film since "Casino" (my personal favorite of his many great films next to King Of Comedy and Goodfellas)with this tremendously entertaining and dramatically effective biopic about "aviator", filmmaker, businessman Howard Hughes.  If there is one problem with this film (and this is the sort of problem most films should have) is that I wish it could have been even longer and gone even further ahead into Hughes' fascinating life.  There was a good deal that happened to Hughes long after this film takes place that would have been interesting to see executed on the big screen.  The film does not in my mind white wash his persona or make him out to be a hero.  The film in many ways shows us all how one man can be a visionary and at the same time completely vulnerable and fallible all at the same time.  In many ways the message of this film is weakness can exist among geniuses...Even greed, sexism, prejudice and ego.  But also as the film opens and so effectively suggests (QUARANTINE) much of who we are comes from our upbringing, childhood and what we learned as youths to formulate our perspectives on the world around us.  Leonardo Dicaprio gives the best performance I have seen to date from him in this film and Robert Richardson's breathtaking cinematography soars to new heights.  I also admired many of the supporting performances from the rest of the uniformly excellent cast (i.e. Ian Holm, John C. Reilly, Cate Blanchette, Alec Baldwin and Alan Alda).  There are also sequences in this film among the best I have ever seen (i.e. Beverly Hills plane crash, door knob, projection room).  I was one of the few people who loved Gangs Of New York and it is nice to see Scorsese back at the top of his game again.  Steven Spielberg/Woody Allen you need pay attention and take note...Scorsese's making you guys look bad.

reviewText: Martin Scorsese has wisely telescoped the sprawling life of Howard Hughes into approximately 20 years in his handsomely mounted, "The Aviator," probably because of a couple of things: one, it was the most creative period in Hughes' life and two, it was the twenty years in which Hughes descended little by little into madness...his own personal Hell.The choice of Leonardo Di Caprio to portray Hughes was a controversial one in that Di Caprio, though extremely popular with the movie-going public, particularly young girls, is still looked upon with skepticism by the critics. Why this is I am not sure, for if you look at the body of his work, including "Titanic" in which he was at the very least a charming performer, he has done some excellent work: "Gilbert Grape," "A Boy's Life" and "Basketball Diaries" to name several.But it will be Howard Hughes that will become Di Caprio's signature role in this, what you might call, the middle period of his career. His performance as Hughes is driven, attractive, charismatic: so much of what Di Caprio does with this character he does with his expressive face and eyes. Note the look in his besotted eyes when he first sees Katherine Hepburn (Cate Blanchett, spot-on perfect) and the body language when she dumps him.Di Caprio knows when to hold back, he knows how to listen, and he knows how to use his face in close-up, in middle shots and his body in long shots.And when the periods of insanity overtake him, it looks and feels scary and genuine because it comes from deep inside him. This is by no means a surface performance: Di Caprio has put his heart and his soul into understanding Hughes...and it shows.The physical production of "The Aviator" is gorgeous and Scorsese has decided to film most of the film in saturated 40's style Technicolor. Of particular note are the scenes of Hughes flying, which of course were blue screened but done so expertly then nary a seam shows. But what else could we expect from the King of Details, Scorsese?And like Orpheus playing his Lyre and soothing all that hear him as well as stopping rivers from flowing, Scorsese anoints Howard Hughes with the impranteur Genius. And all who come in contact with Hughes are at least fascinated and at best cannot resist him. Scorsese then gives Hughes the same mythic status as that of Orpheus and like Orpheus, Hughes blindly descends into Hell, his own personal Hell, searching for something he is doomed to never find.

reviewText: Leonard DiCaprio (Titanic, Gangs Of New York) portays legendary director and aviaton designer Howard Hughes who was plummeted into a world of lies, sex, conspiracy and his own inner demons. Throughout the movie we see what really happened behind the scenes and during his own life as he tries to make his name a gargantuan one as he builds the largest aircrafts ever designed and dating famous actresses. There's a star studded array of cast here and their all perfect even if some of them dont get that much screen time. Cate Blanchett (The Lord Of The Rings Trilogy, The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou) channels Hepburn with honest truth, Kate Beckinsale (Underworld '03, Van Helsing) plays Ava Gardner with sass and Gwen Stefani (lead singer of No Doubt) is cute as Jean Harlow. Alec Baldwin (The Cooler, The Edge) plays the owner of Pan-Am, Alan Alda (tv's MASH, Canadian Bacon) plays Senator Brewster who questions Hughes on trial. John C. Reilly (Criminal, The Perfect Storm) and Matt Ross (American Pyscho, PCU) play Hughes friends and co-workers. It's a long movie, yes but I really liked this movie a lot and it gives DiCaprio one of his best performances so far. Scorsese hits on all cylinders here and after its done you just want more of Howard Hughes but I think it ended satifyingly enough. Also starring Edward Herrmann (The Lost Boys, The Shaft), Brent Spiner (Star Trek: Fist Contact and Nemesis), Ian Holm (Lord Of The Rings Trilogy, The Sweet Hereafter) and this is the 6th film that has Jude Law (Alfie, Closer) in it this fall. The crash scene where Hughes gets injured crashing into the buildings just shows how good DiCaprio is.
summary: The Aviator soars with DiCaprio at his best..Scorsese scores

reviewText: Considering the fact that I've never been enthralled with the enigmatic Howard Hughes and the fact that Leonardo diCaprio is not one of my favorite actors, I was pleasantly surprised with Martin Scorcese's THE AVIATOR.  It's a big, epic, sumptuously filmed spectacle that maintained my interest.  Scorcese smartly focuses on a definite time period in Hughes' life, and although the movie's ending seems empty and unfulfilled, the nearly three hour film is still packed with enough pathos and style to earn its critical kudos and its five Oscars.Cate Blanchett who won a supporting actress Oscar wisely chooses not to "imitate" the legendary Katherine Hepburn, but using mannerisms and voice inflections, she brings us a startingly realistic portrait of this venerated star.  Leo does incredibly well overall, but there were times when I found him to be posturing rather than acting, and while impressed with his performance, a stronger actor may have made Howard a little more empathic.  A little more understanding of how he developed his obsessive-compulsive behavior may have benefitted the film as well.  The rest of the cast is excellent:  Alan Alda in his Oscar nominated role as Senator Bennett is brilliant; John C. Reilly as Hughes' financial manager is also very good as always.  Jude Law shows up as Errol Flynn, but isn't a major part of the film; I was disappointed in Kate Beckinsale's turn as Ava Gardner.  Beckinsale certainly has the physical voluptuousness of Gardne, but her performance was merely eye candy with little depth.  Gwen Stefani's brief appearance as Jean Harlow was better than Beckinsale's.Overall, though, this movie is a fine example of quality film-making including its soaring score by Oscar winner Howard Shore, the cinematography, sets, and costumes.  THE AVIATOR is a good representation of both Scorcese's prowess and epic Hollywood film making.

reviewText: I'm not that big a fan of biopics. They tend to be black-or-white, laudatory or steeped in evilness, depending on the subject. I'm also not that crazy about pretty-boy DiCaprio, this decade's Johnny Depp. Having said all that, there's some good stuff in this film. The early part is overly episodic, jumping ahead a year or a decade from one scene to the next, and the dialogue in the opening scene is especially hard to follow. But it doesn't really matter because the opening scene contributes very little to the rest of the film, in which Hughes springs forth full-grown as a genius engineer and film-maker with no indication of how he was educated or trained himself. The bulk of the action is late-1930s to late-1940s, focusing on the Hercules transport (the "Spruce Goose") and Hughes' development of the XF-11 spy plane and his breaking various world records for speed and distance, and also on his affairs with Katherine Hepburn and Ava Gardner. I understand why the story didn't follow him into the Las Vegas years and all that, but still, the biographical info included was extremely selective. There's no mention of his marriages and children, for instance. The flying sequences are interesting and the crash-sequence is heart-stopping in its true-to-life details, but you can't make a whole film out of just that. I'd say this one was about fifty percent successful.
summary: Could have been much, much better

reviewText: Martin Scorsese's "The Aviator" is a look at about two decades in the life of millionaire Howard Hughes (DiCaprio).  As the movie opens, he is spending tons of money to get his film "Hell's Angels" filmed to his satisfaction.  His passion for aviation leads him to acquire TWA, develope a spy plane, and battle with Senator Ralph Owen (Alda) and Pan-Am president Juan Trippe (Baldwin) over international flights.  The movie ends with the long awaited flight of the "Spruce Goose".  Along the way, he romances Katherine Hepburn (Blanchett), Ava Gardner (Beckinsale), and Faith Domeregue (Kelli Garner).  He also battles an obsessive compulsive condition that nearly hobbles him a number of times."The Aviator" is an unflinching look at Howard Hughes' life.  The highs and the lows are portrayed equally, showing him to be an intelligent and driven man with a debilitating sickness.  DiCaprio does an adequate job as Hughes (I find DiCaprio to be overrated).  Cate Blanchett is excellent as Hepburn, and supporting roles by Reilly, Baldwin, and Alda hold the film together.  I would argue that the biggest drawback to the film is the somewhat abrupt ending.  Not knowing anything about Hughes, it left me wondering what happened next.

reviewText: Recognition for Martin Scorsese, famous for his cult-classic dramas such as Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, and Goodfellas, from the Motion Picture Academy has been since been long overdue. Several critics proclaimed in 2002 that his extensive filmography alone justified him being awarded the golden statuette while still others argued that merit came before popularity and legacy anytime. Thankfully, he failed to garner a win two years ago for Gangs of New York, a wretched train-wreck that was hardly worth recognition in the light of his glamorous filmmaking legacy, though on the other hand it was truly painful to have seen the award given to Roman Polanski, the infamous coward, pervert, and all-around loathsome character. The Aviator, once again starring heart-throb Leonardo DiCaprio, may at last be the picture that scores Scorsese that ever elusive award statuette with critics abound applauding it and audiences flocking consistently w weekend in and weekend out to see it. Can Oscar be too far off in his future? Only time, as well as the votes of academy members, will tell for sure.The story centers on but a small window of the life of the legendary Howard Hughes, from 1930 to 1947 to be precise, the time in which he was the most active before leaving Hollywood, as well as the world, and becoming a total recluse hiding out in his Las Vegas casinos until 1971 when he died of kidney failure. Born the son of a Texas drill bit inventor in 1905, Howard Hughes was taught by his mother to fear germs and disease, which included any contact that would result in direct contact with them. When his father died, he was left with seventy-five percent stake in Hughes Tool Co. and looked toward the West to expand his already immense fortune. Moving to the state of California, Hughes set up shop as a hot-shot Hollywood producer, starting off with Hell's Angels, a black and white World War I epic essentially the equivalent to today's B-action flicks. He became known as the eccentric perfectionist, waiting excruciating periods of time simply for cloud formations in the background of aerial sequences, thus sending the production cost soaring. In the end the film went down with the largest production budget in cinema history at the time, costing a then whopping four million dollars. Hughes would go on to the test the very limits of the Motion Picture Association's ratings board with the violently graphic Scarface in 1932 and the sexually explicit The Outlaw in 1943. Also during this time, Hughes, a dashing young billionaire and the toast of tinsel town, romanced many of the most dazzling starlets of the era including Katherine Hepburn, Ava Gardner, Jean Harlow, and Faith Domergue. Expanding upon his fascination with the aviation industry, Howard Hughes goes on to purchase the airline industry that would become TWA. And working under contracts for the Department of Defense of the United States of America during World War II, his creation of The Hercules, or better known under its more infamous name the "Spruce Goose", would land Hughes in hot water and be pressured to collapse all control of the aviation industry to Pan Am by Senator Ralph Owen Brewster, supposedly on the payroll of Pan Am owner Juan Trippe. Hughes' eccentric and bizarre behavior, which would later be categorized as either a bipolar disorder or paranoid-schizophrenia, was exposed to the public and he faces scrutiny at the hands of a corrupt system of which he is willing to go to war with to prove his innocence.The story for The Aviator resurrects the aberrant life of Howard Hughes and presents it in the grandiose, nostalgic, and mythological style that only Martin Scorsese could have achieved so seamlessly and effectively all at the same time. In spite of its lavish three-hour time length, the film's flow and consistency is never once interrupted by abrupt slow periods, nor does it ever outpace its audience's ability to divulge information at a reasonable pace. Already at this point it is leaps and bounds ahead of the bumbling monstrosity that was Gangs of New York. And although the first few minutes of the picture in which Hughes' mother bathes the young boy in a tub of water in a dimly lit room and speaks to him of avoiding the disease-filled residence of a neighbor may seem a bit awkward when it first starts out, given time it will be made all the more understandable as eloquent symbolism to the sporadic nature of Howard Hughes.Howard Hughes, whether he be the man, the legend, or quite possibly a combination of the two, truly is the focus of this picture and Leonardo DiCaprio, having been snubbed in years past for his roles in both Titanic and Gangs of New York, captures brilliantly the eccentric aviator's maverick personality and from the very first scenes instantly grapples the attention of his audience in much the same way as Hughes would have wanted it done. Whether or not he receives a golden statuette this time around, let alone receives a nomination at the Academy Awards ceremony, DiCaprio, in the short years since his breakout performance in the smash-hit Titanic, has built up quite an impressive resume none-the-less, especially given that he has actually demonstrated true acting potential rather then simply riding the wave of pure publicity and hype. Cate Blanchett, an especially gifted actress who has rounded up in recent years particularly well-deserved acclaim from critics for her roles in The Lord of the Rings trilogy and Veronica Guerin, reflects perfectly the extraordinary, if not often curious, nature of the late-Katharine Hepburn. Though this is almost certainly going to be overlooked by the members of the academy when it comes time to divvy up nominations for the Best Supporting Actor category this year, John C. Reilly's portrayal of Noah Dietrich, Hughes' company accountant and dear friend, deserves recognition for providing a structured counter-balance personality to the divergent Howard Hughes. Alan Alda, famous for his portrayal of Hawkeye Pierce in the acclaimed television series M*A*S*H, proves that in all his years in the glitzy Hollywood business he has failed to lose his touch, giving a brilliantly stark performance as the conniving Senator Ralph Owen Brewster. In a particular scene in which the senator invites Howard to a luncheon meeting in a last ditch effort to avoid a public hearing and have him fold on the refutation of his new aviation bill, he appears as though he takes pleasure in tormenting Hughes' now apparent mental condition, going so far as to pick up a glass at the last minute and place a smudge mark on it directly in Hughes' line of sight. Splendidly Hughes, refusing to be baited and racking his bodily functions to fight back the affects of his mental condition, stuns Brewster by drinking straight out of that glass and forces him to be on the defensive, a position no one, let alone a senator of the United States Congress, finds comfortable. Surely not everything that Hughes did, most notably taking money from the government for projects he never completed or delivered and bribing military contractors, can be defined as just but he can not be blamed entirely for that given that those were the sign of the times. If anything, this investigation brought about a change in the way the aviation industry would be dealt with and Hughes' stern rebuttal of Brewster's true intentions single-handedly restored the idea of capitalism in yet another branch of the U.S. industrial system.Not all the performances in The Aviator were necessarily as successful in their portrayal of the famous stars and starlets of the era as the last set of performers were, nor were some of the casting decisions. Jude Law, in what seems to be his twentieth appearance in a film - whether it be a mere cameo or an actual standing role - this year, gives a decent portrayal of Errol Flynn but one wonders why he is even in the film seeing as how he does little in the direct effect of Hughes' life or legend. Kate Beckingsale's role as Ava Gardner is not particularly unnecessary, nor can it exactly be described in such a negative way but there does appear to be some level of confusion as to how prominent of a role she actually played in Howard Hughes life and what she truly meant to him in the end. In the first couple of scenes we see her in, she seems as though she is nothing more then another Hollywood floozy coddling after the eccentric billionaire. This changes dramatically when later in the film she returns to see Howard in his retched condition alone in his office and cleans him up for his appearance in front of Brewster's public committee hearing, giving the sense as though she were mothering him a bit. Had more background information been provided on Miss Gardner or if Scorsese had gone more in-depth with their particular relationship together then there may not have been this sense of befuddlement the audience has concerning her particular character. One has to question why so much hype was built up by the entertainment industry press surrounding Gwen Stefani's portrayal as Jean Harlow. Her performance, if one can truly call it that, was quite disappointing, singling her out as nothing more then eye-candy and barely drawling out a pathetic one line of dialogue.Overall, The Aviator, in much the same light as its subject of discussion, is larger then life itself and for what seems once in a blue moon on the screen that does not go aggressively against it, ensuring its rightful place as the film to beat this awards season. The film ends rather abruptly with Hughes standing directly in front of a grungy bathroom mirror, repeating the phrase "...wave of the future", and should the audience feel angered or disappointed by this conclusion then Martin Scorsese will have successfully pulled off his desired effect. True to form, the life of Howard Hughes' was never the same again from that moment on. For the mythic man who had done so much in his lifetime up to that point and at the same time had far more yet to accomplish, Hughes' condition spiraled out of control, reducing him to live in total obscurity in one of his several casinos in Las Vegas, dying of kidney failure. Far from the man who made the motion-picture no one wanted to release, wooed the finest women in Hollywood, and built and flew the largest plane in the world when no one believed it would even get a foot off the ground. That, ladies and gentlemen, is truly the disheartening conclusion to the eccentric, yet majestic, life of Mr. Howard Hughes. The man who perhaps was greatly overshadowed by the legendary figure he helped create and whose shoes he could not fill. Scorsese, a man always willing to be daring and take a risk when it comes to the exact look and feel of a particular film, brilliantly - how many times can that be said of him - captures in each year that is represented the accurate visual style of the color film of that time period, whether it was the old-fashioned Cinecolor or the two-strip Technicolor film. And as the story progresses, the film's appearance matures and fills out more, giving The Aviator a visual quality all its own, setting its miles apart from the competition. Undoubtedly this film will not be everyone's cup of tea, as disappointing as that may be to hear given as how apparently masterful it is, but rest assured that given the proper number of viewings and a through understanding of the life and time of the man who was Howard Hughes, it will be easy for anyone to see as to why this will be the film that gives Scorsese his absurdly overdue Academy Award this year.

reviewText: Martin Scorsese's "The Aviator" is a big film in both conception and achievement. It's easy to understand why Scorsese, a director naturally drawn to outsize, outwardly impractical projects, was drawn to the story of Howard Hughes, a man who went for broke in everything he did--whether it was making movies, building aircraft, or--tragically--his final descent into madness. Scorsese obviously senses a kindred spirit in the obsessive, visionary Hughes, and he responds with a cinematic extravaganza that Hughes surely would appreciate, even if the warts-and-all portrayal of his life wouldn't please him. Scorsese--with the help of his regular collaborators, cinematographer Robert Richardson and film editor Thelma Schoonmaker--creates an amazing tribute to Hughes, including some of the most amazing aviation scenes ever put on film. (A plane crash sequence may be the most harrowing of its kind in cinematic history--my guess is that "The Aviator" will NEVER be shown on an airline!) As always, Scorsese gets amazing performances from his cast, beginning with the great (yes, the GREAT) Leonardo DiCaprio as Hughes. It should be obvious to everyone by now that judging DiCaprio by "Titanic" is like judging Johnny Depp by "21 Jump Street." DiCaprio expertly captures the contradictory, often downright weird behavior patterns of Hughes, giving us the portrait of a whole man who is far more admirable and sympathetic than not. He even contrives to match the familiar, furrowed-brow look of Hughes without falling into caricature. As Katharine Hepburn, Cate Blanchett works similar magic, capturing Hepburn's world-famous voice and mannerisms superbly yet giving a three-dimensional performance rather than a mere impersonation. There's also a fine supporting performance by Alan Alda as an oily senator who shills for Hughes's enemies in the aviation business. "The Aviator" isn't quite perfect--it could use a little trimming here and there, and the off-putting Gwen Stefani is badly miscast in her mercifully brief appearance as Jean Harlow. But as a tribute to one great American dreamer by another, it is a consistently impressive and entertaining film.
summary: Hughes and Scorsese: Two bigger-than-life heroes.

reviewText: "The Aviator" is a 2 3/4-hour extravaganza that follows 20 years in the life of multi-millionaire industrialist Howard Hughes, whose innovation and willingness to spend his considerable fortune on his passions changed the film and aviation industries in the United States. "The Aviator" captured 4 Academy Awards in 2005 and was nominated for about 100 awards by critical, professional, and other organizations in the US and the UK. Director Martin Scorsese has translated the most productive years in Hughes' life into a visual and dramatic tour de force, beginning as Hughes takes Hollywood by storm in 1927 and ending shortly after his victory over Senator Ralph Owen Brewster in securing international flight rights for TWA in 1947. The film ends before Hughes' days at RKO Studios.As "The Aviator" opens, Howard Hughes (Leonardo DiCaprio) is using his drill bit fortune to assemble the largest private air force in the world for his first film, "Hell's Angels", which became the most expensive film ever produced at the time. Hughes went on to make a couple of other notable films and to head RKO Studios, but "The Aviator" focuses on Hughes' aeronautical achievements more than his Hollywood career. Hughes' long relationship with Katharine Hepburn (Cate Blanchett), in whom he met his match, is depicted sympathetically and a bit wistfully, as if Hughes' life would have turned out differently had Kate stuck around. "The Aviator" takes us through Howard Hughes' ambition to build a passenger plane that would fly above the weather, his acquisition of TWA, his 1935 speed record, his record-breaking circumnavigation of the globe, his war contracts during World War II, and the crash that nearly killed him in 1946. The film's dramatic climax is probably the 1947 Senate hearings in which Hughes' battled Senator Brewster (Alan Alda) for TWA's right to compete with Pan Am Airways in international flights. We see Hughes' famous obsessive-compulsive behavior gradually become a corrosive force in his life, but the film ends before he became completely debilitated by it.Thanks to Leonardo DiCaprio, Howard Hughes' enthusiasm -indeed obsession- with aviation and his limitless ambition come across in every frame of "The Aviator". The supporting cast is all-star. Cate Blanchett seems to play Katharine Hepburn as a combination of the real woman and of her public image, which may or may not be the best approach, but it's what viewers will expect. John C. Reilly is Hughes' talented, long-suffering business manager, Noah Dietrich. Willem Dafoe, Jude Law, Gwen Stefani, and Ian Holm all have small roles. Kate Beckinsale is the glamourous actress Ava Gardner, Hughes' longtime friend. And Alec Baldwin is Pan Am's cunning president Juan Trippe. Dante Ferretti and Francesca Lo Schiavo's award-winning art direction and Robert Richardson's cinematography make "The Aviator" a visual delight. The incredible recreation of Los Angeles' Coconut Grove club, seen over the course of 3 decades, deserves special attention.The downside is that "The Aviator" is long and sometimes feels that way. The omission of most of Hughes' Hollywood relationships and his time at RKO may disappoint film buffs. And Scorsese's attempt to explain Hughes' obsessive-compulsive disorder by alluding to a childhood cholera epidemic is awkward. But Howard Hughes lived an extraordinary and eventful life, and "The Aviator" is a celebration of his achievements and a lament of his flaws. It's an entertaining epic of a larger-than-life American innovator.
summary: Visually Stunning Biopic of H. Hughes' Innovation & Ambition

reviewText: I couldn't tell you if this is a truly accurate portrayal of Hughes' adventures and accomplishments, I just know that this movie rubbed me the wrong way. The last hour is excruciating to watch, with seemingly endless descents into madness that were shown in such graphic detail the audience becomes bored long before they could become fascinated or shocked. DiCaprio did indeed deliver a rather dramatic performance (if not a little too prima donna-ish), but it is painfully obvious that Hughes is a broken man less than an hour into the movie-why they insisted on showing each and every mental breakdown he had and then ending it abruptly on a note so sour the viewer is in desperate need of palette refreshment-I have no clue. Gwen Stefani's short but quirky little appearance might be the biggest highlight of the movie, which I found just plain bizarre. And after experiencing a plane crash so disturbingly jarring, a self-destruction was obviously imminent for Hughes, particularly when everything he'd already undergone is taken into account. And yet.....it dragged on for almost another hour. He deserves the recognition for his accomplishments in the air, but digging this deep into his ghastly personal life seems unnecessary. This movie wants him remembered as the brilliant psycho, which is not how he should be remembered. All in all, the first hour was tolerable, but as the movie goes on...and on....and ON.....it becomes agonizing. I do not recommend viewing this at all, unless you want to spend two or three hours watching a deeply disturbed man slowly destroy himself, and at one point rolling around nude in an empty room, screaming in agony and urinating in milk bottles for 20 to 30 minutes.
summary: Whether this is an accurate portrayal or not......

reviewText: The AVIATOR for me was a load of fun. As someone born in the 50s this movie shows how much fun it must have been to live in the first half of the 20th century and have money. DiCaprio does a fine job portraying Howard HUGHES, a true visionary who was afflicted with mental illnesses that, at the time, were never publicly discussed. The movie does not gloss over his eccentricities but fully addresses his unhealthy preoccupation with germs and other compulsive bahaviors. It even spends time at the beginning of the movie to show his childhood where his mother planted the seeds of his anxieties.Cate Blanchett does a fine job in her portrayal of Katherine HEPBURN who had a love affair with HUGHES'S before she met Spencer TRACY.  Also we see hollywood in it's heyday with appearances by Louie B. MAYER, Ava GARDNER, Jean HARLOW and Errol FLYNN (played by Jude Law) among others. Alan ALDA capably plays a cowardly and corrupt senator standing in the way of HUGHES'S business intentions. The movie is nothing to speak of as a great thought provoking experience. It is what it is- a very entertaining look at Mr. HUGHES life (with some very fine flying sequences thrown in).
summary: Not thought provoking, just GREAT FUN

reviewText: Representing a quantum leap in the cinematic relationship between director Martn Scorcese and Leonardo Dicaprio, "The Aviator" flies on an astounding central performance and Scorcese's visual prowess.  Dicaprio is finally becoming the kind of actor we have been waiting for.  He always had it in him, but was straightjacketed by "Titanic" and subsequent roles that never really gelled with him.  But his portrayal of the ambitious but deeply troubled Howard Hughes is a revelation, as Dicaprio finally grows up into mature actor.  Scorcese masterfully pulls great work not only from Dicaprio, but from his stellar ensemble cast.  Cate Blanchett rocks the screen as an uncanny Katherine Hepburn and Alec Balwin and Alan Alda are a couple of excellent sleazeballs, a airline mogul and senator repectively.  Kate Beckinslae glows with charisma as the starlet Ava Gardner and John C. Reilly hits just the right notes as Howard huges close assitant, one of the principal witnesses to Hughes' steady downward spiral.But the film kicks off in 1927, with Howard Hugghes trying to take over Hollywood by financing the giant World War One aerial epic "Hells' Angels."  The shoot is troubled, with Hughes spending 4 million dollars of his own money, but it becomes a smash.  The filming of the movie provides us with a hint of what Scorcese has done with the films' flying scenes which are incredible, aided by the bracing cinematography of Robert Richardson (Kill Bill, Platoon) and the sure handed editing of Thelma Schoonmaker (Raging Bull, Gangs of New York).  Along the course of the movie Scorcese shows that he has a deep love of old school Hollywood, showing reverence for the old haunt Coconut Grove and the many stars of the time, including Jean Harlow (Gwen Stefani) and Errol Flynn (Jude Law).  Hughes is shown here as the ambitious and driven golden boy he was, throwing Hollywood one hit after another while building an airline empire with TWA and bedding some of the most beautiful women of the time.  But even here, early in the film, Hughes mental breakdown begins.  Undiagnosed obsessive compulsive disorder is slowly eating away at him, and Dicaprio shows every fatal step with nervous looks and a dead on Texas accent.As the film progresses, Hughes begins a slow but sure slide into seclusion.  His relationships don't last and a breakup with Hepburn proves especially damaging.  After a test flight goes horribly awry and Hughes is left crippled, he takes refuge in is home, where he lives naked and unkempt, urinating into empty milk bottles and stammering wildly.  Many aspects of this film maybe grandiose, but Scorcese proves that he still knows how to explore the dark side of humanity via all too vulnerable male leads.  The film may not be souful, and it wasn't meant to be, but is a Scorcese film, one that delves deeply into parts of the pysche that are often unpleasant.  Some will not find the film engrossing, and if you are not a fan of Scorcese's style, "The Aviator" won't change your mind.  But if you give the film a chance, it will stick with you.  Scorcese still has it, and now, so does Dicaprio.

reviewText: To the two reviewers below and others thinking the same thing about the color. There isn't suppose to be green in the first half of the film (it was this was in the theater on purpose)! It represents the two-tone color look of the 1920's. The green is a bluish hue, just read the IGN.com review and it will explain this to you and why Scorsese did the color this way. Now on to the review...I didn't know much about Howard Hughes going in other than the fact he was a rich recluse who sometimes rented entire hotels just so he could stay alone in solitude for nights on end. But after seeing this film I really feel I know the guy. I am not a fan of Leonardo DiCaprio by any means, but I have to admit he nails the part here. All the supporting actors are great as well, with Cate Blanchett as Katharine Hepburn really standing out by copying her voice and body movements perfectly. I really like Clint Eastwood and his film Million Dollar Baby, but Martin Scorsese should have finally gotten the Oscar this time around that he should have won 14 years ago for Goodfellas. The Aviator is worth owning and it stands proud beside my copies of Raging Bull and Goodfellas.
summary: A Note on the "Defective" Color on DVD

reviewText: I at least hope not.  All of the reviews are very good on here, but I have to be honest, this is one of my top 10 favorite movies of all-time.  I have never been a leonardo fan, until now.  I will be reviewing the 2-disc edition here.The movie itself is wonderful in showing us a GOOD version of the howard hughes story.  the commentary does a lot of explaining hwo you can't tell a 100% true life story of a this guy, so they took facts and built on that to make this movie.  They go over many historical events and seem to hit many of the good ones.  But leonardo's portrayal is magnificent.  Not only is he perfect for the young free spending howard, but also for the older role.  There is a wonderful part in the movie that is showing you just how crazy this guy is.  He sees a dirty janitor cleaning, howard asks somebody if that guy works for him, he tells the guy to fire him.  I thought it was a great part, but the commentary gives you great insight of how he was supposed to be seeing himself years from now all dirty and stuff.  It doesn't make the movie any better, but it is always good to have an understanding.  So it would take to long to go over this long ass movie, but it is awesome and I have to say that the court scene is definitely one of my favorite scenes in cinema history.The commentary is pretty good, btu not enough talking, not coherent enough, and A LOT of repeated stuff from the interviews.And all of the interviews and documentaries are well worth watching.  There is also a lot of stuff on the miniatures and how they got the action scenes to screen.  Also costume and music featurettes.  Overall the extras get a 4/5, it's just I can't rate the extras anywhere near the actual movie, it is truly inspiring.

reviewText: Basically, I hated it. There: I got it out. The story was boring to me, and it was a very long one, at that. I suspect that I have not had any exposure to what another reviewer referred to as the "Hughes Legend", (I think the quote is accurate). I guess the movie would be more interesting with more familiarity with the enigmatic Hughes and his life.Despite my negative opening, I have to give credit for a few things. One is the acting of Leonardo Di Caprio, which was absolutely awesome. Di Caprio put on a stellar performance in what must have been a singularly demanding and difficult role. This has been the best I have seen from Di Caprio, and he deserves all accolades for it. Di Caprio truly shone in this movie.Secondly, the visual presentation and photography were excellent. The attention to detail was excellent, which helped carry the viewer into the story and the time. I would add that I was disappointed that so much of the aircraft scenes relied on computer graphics to achieve. Call me old fashioned, but some flying replicas would have been nice, if possible. It has to be emphasised that some of the aircraft scenes were the best in the movie, so this comment is really a quibble of mine.Other notable performances were Allan Alda and Alec Baldwin. Both put in great performances and were brilliant in their supporting roles.I would not recommend "The Aviator", due to long slow march of it into sedation. However, for those with an interest in Howard Hughes and aviation, it would be of interest. For any Di Caprio fans, Di Caprio's acting makes enduring the movie almost worth it. He was great!

reviewText: I desperately wanted to like this movie.  In the end, I cam away unsatisfied.Martin Scorcese is an interesting filmmaker.  I would love to rave at his brilliance, but I have always found his movies since the late 80's to be stilted, stylized and extremely violent.Yet, I loved Gangs of New York - perhaps more for the history involved.  The Age of Innocence is simply a lovely and very good movie.  The Aviator is just mediocre.My first impression is that the film crew knew nothing about aviation whatsoever.  In an early scene, Hughes flies the famous H-1 at 350 miles per hour in an open cockpit without goggles. Unless there is direct evidence that this happened, I find it hard to believe.  The CG graphics look very fake to me as well.  The scenes of filming Hells Angels are clearly what I call digital masturbation.  Just not as great as the real thing.  The planes look clearly fake.  The scene where Hughes is filming from the plane seems more incredible then reality.As far as the acting, the actors seem stilted.  I frankly didn't think very much of Cate Blanchet's portrayal of Hepburn.  I know it is a stylized version of Hepburn, but it just didn't grab me.  Alec Baldwin makes Juan Trippe (the founder of the now defunct Pan American, and an incredible and far more important figure in aviation who deserves his own movie) is made out to be a egomaniacal freak by Baldwin.  Baldwin seems to be miscast in Pearl Harbor as Doolittle, and hear he brings a evil patina to Trippe.  Was Trippe evil because he wanted to use everything in his power to stop other airlines?To me DiCaprio seems unconvincing in this role.  He is a very good actor, but this role required someone with a more menacing and rugged personality.  To me, DiCaprio seems like a little kid in this role.  He doesn't even resemble Hughes at all.My other peeve with this movie is the subtle portrayal and foreshadowing of Hughes upcoming mental breakdown - it is a shock - shock! - to see him lose his mind.  NOT.  Here the entry of Hughes social phobia is so thick you would need to be a moron not to see it.  It just distracts from the movie.  Hughes was making decisions and running his business until the mid 70's.  In this movie Hughes seems to become Jekyll - paralyzed by madness one moment, and Hyde in another moment fighting for his business interests or whatever else without any hint of real madness.  Somehow it seems very iffy.  And this film offers no real answers.  For crying out loud, my mother told me about germs and I drink milk, I am not living in a Vegas hotel naked and refusing to cut my nails!!  Can we have some subtle suggestion of why he was so paranoid about disease?  Also, the scene of Hughes as a child with his mother seems to have incestual implications from the suggestive way its filmed. There are other very odd suggestions in this movie as well that I felt really bogged the movie down with a strange quality.  Is Scorcese putting these things here on purpose, or does he not realize they are there through his overly thick eyebrows?  Yeeesh.In short, this movie is worth seeing on several levels.  It is not a bad movie by any means despite my two stars. However, I wouldn't say that beyond some terrific costuming and recreation of scenes in the 30's and 40's will you be given any idea of Hughes contributions to aviation (rivets - that was it Martin? A monoplane?), filmmaking or anything else.  You are left with a lot of thoughts of themes that may or may not be there, undeveloped characters, and a whole lot of weirdness.  For a real descent into weirdness, may I recommend this movie and Howard and Me? I still laugh at the weirdness possible - Howard, would you like my used Kleenex to use?  How about an open bottle of milk?Frankly, the movie made me curious about the real Hughes.  Having seen Hells Angels, it seems Hughes was not such a bad filmmaker.  In fact, Hells Angels is a very entertaing movie! The Outlaw seems tame now, because of Jane Russell's ahem overdeveloped breathing ability, but in the 1940's it was smutty as smutty can be.  I think the movie would have been better if Hughes had been remembering the different episodes of his life all while lying in his bed in Vegas wondering how he ended up there. It would have been a much more effective device for telling a very wothwhile story.  But, hey who am I?  I don't have an American Express commercial nor a constant blather on TCM about letterboxing.  If there is any cosmic justice however, Martin will end up in heaven with Howard blabbering about the tiny tv screens and the lack of letterboxing.  Well, my sick thought, but frankly, you may some sick thoughts too after watching a movie that doesn't live up to the potential of it's very worthwhile subject matter.
summary: A great life - a mediocre movie

reviewText: Martin Scorsese's sweeping and epic portrait of Howard Hughes gives the legendary aviator and movie mogul the class and respect he deserves, beginning with the surprisingly perfect casting of Leonardo DiCaprio.  Those who believed DiCaprio was miscast in Scorsese's previous Gangs of New York will be marvelled as he gives the best performance of his career here.  Focusing on the most prolific period of Hughes' life, we see Hughes as the glamorous playboy and rich movie producer, but he is shown first and foremost as a brilliant aviator whose aeronautical advances bring both praise and ridicule.  John Logan's script is respectful, focusing on this period of Hughes' life and ending before his life took a final downward spiral, and the casting for the most part is superb.  Cate Blanchett shines in her Oscar winning role as Katherine Hepburn, while Kate Beckinsale is miscast as Ava Gardner.  The rest of the cast, including Oscar nominee Alan Alda, Alec Baldwin, and Di Caprio's fellow Gangs of New York alumni John C. Reilly, do teriffic work.  As a whole, the Aviator is a big budget Scorsese masterpiece that ranks up there with the director's other modern day classics, and like Hughes himself, DiCaprio and co. soar high.

reviewText: I must admit up front that this wasn't a film I was excited to see in the theater (I've never been a fan of Martin Scorsese films)...but with everything I read about it, I really was shocked that it didn't win the Best Picture Oscar this year (I guess I'm not the only one who's not a fan of Scorsese). This epic film seemed to have all the ingredients that the Academy likes in their Best Picture selection, but maybe it was too much a reminder of "The English Patient" or else Hollywood doesn't think much of Howard Hughes.After watching the film, I completely understand why it didn't win (though I haven't seen "Million Dollar Baby" either). Its difficult to sit through a nearly 3 hour movie where the main character is obsessive compulsive. It makes for a very uncomfortable viewing experience! The film has its moments though...particularly EVERY SCENE with Cate Blanchett as the Academy's favorite actress Katherine Hepburn. She is simply  great and marvelous in her role, well deserving of her Oscar win. In a way, I wished this film was more about her than Howard Hughes. The other scenes I liked were the flying sequences and the Senate hearings when Howard Hughes manages to overcome his eccentric phobias to defend his name and turn the tables on a very corrupt Senator, played impressively by Alan Alda. That's about it, as far as what I liked in this movie. The rest of the time as I viewed it, I couldn't help but think that maybe someone should send a copy of this movie to Michael Jackson. Maybe seeing the obsessive-compulsions of another genius and how it nearly destroyed him will serve as a wake up call to MJ...but on second thought, probably not.The ending of this film I thought was weak and incomplete. I honestly don't know anything about Howard Hughes, and because this film just ends with Hughes rambling one of his repetative sentences, we don't know what happens to him, and after sitting through 3 hours of a bio-pic, it doesn't encourage me to want to learn more about the guy. I did see some similarities between the way Scorsese made this film and Orson Welles' "Citizen Kane", but if it was intentional, it was a very weak attempt to create that level of cinematic brilliance.On one positive, yet unintentionally ironic note...I thought it was interesting that Leonardo DiCaprio played Howard Hughes, who helped TWA become a major competing airline to Pan Am...considering that Leonardo played a con-man who pretends to be a Pan Am pilot in Steven Spielberg's "Catch Me if You Can." I think maybe watching this two films in a double feature might work...but with "The Aviator"...all you'll get is a lot of turbulence with only a few scenes that are truly worth seeing. It doesn't start, however, until at least 40 minutes into the movie when Cate Blanchett makes her first appearance. She makes this film worth seeing. I hope she'll play the role again if Hollywood decides to make a bio-pic on Katherine Hepburn. But if they do...get someone other than Scorsese to direct.
summary: This film runs into severe turbulence...

reviewText: I really liked Martin Scorsese's "The Aviator." It might have been long for some viewers but it did tell the story of Howard Hughes in fragments, just like his life really was. Leonardo DiCaprio did a great job playing Howard Hughes... I was dissapointed that he did not win the Best Actor Oscar for this role since it was an excellent performance... He had to play a character who was a perfectionist, a hypochondriac with obsessive compulsive disorder, a movie producer, a womanizer, an aviator and an overall arrogant/selfish billionaire. However, I must say that the GREATEST asset to this movie was Cate Blanchett's performance...She was OUTSTANDING as Katherine Hepburn, Howard's favorite love interest. WOW!!!! The way she played Katherine Hepburn was pitch perfect: she walked like her, talked like her, ate like her, behaved like her and everything was well done on her part. She truly deserved the Oscar she won last year for Best Supporting Actress. Kate Beckinsale was great as Ava Gardner in the small role that she had on the film. The biggest shock to me was Alan Alda's nomination for Best Supporiting Actor Oscar... Although I LOVE the movie and I think he is a respected veteran actor known for his role from MASH, his performance as the scheming senator was very brief, appearing only towards the end of the movie when him and Howard are at the Senate hearings... so I'm wondering how did that guarantee him an Oscar nomination? Oh well... he's Alan Alda. Other than that it was a movie that is definitely worth seeing. I'm shocked it did not win the Oscar for Best Motion Picture last year, but it luckily took home 5 awards, being the night's most awards per movie.

reviewText: While I wouldn't call The Aviator one of my favorite movies, I did enjoy it. Of course, the stand out of the cast was Leonardo DiCaprio, who did a wonderful job portraying legendary millionaire, filmmaker, and aviator Howard Hughes. The film focuses on Hughes' early life, when he filmed Hell's Angels and The Outlaw. (Thankfully, the film closes before the period of his life in which Hughes became a total recluse, addicted to drugs, wasting away, and suffering from various crippling phobias.) The film also pays some lip service to Hughes' work in the field of aviation, his endless quest for bigger, better planes, and congressional committee hearings that kept Pan Am from being named America's only international air carrier.I am a huge fan of Katherine Hepburn, and Cate Blanchette, while she certainly doesn't look the part, did seem to capture her personality and way of speaking. The relationship between Hughes and Hepburn was a central one in the film, and Blanchette and DiCaprio played it with warmth and tenderness. For their performances alone, this film is worth watching.Overall, I think this is a period piece, and Scorcese and his team did a deft job of capturing the period with costumes, sets, props, and styling. Though a pretty long movie, fun casting surprises (Gwen Stefani as Jean Harlow, Jude Law as Errol Flynn, and Alec Baldwin as Juan Tripp, Kate Beckinsale as Ava Gardner) keep it interesting.
