reviewText: The movie begins as a young Hughes directs one of Scorsese's favorite films, Hell's Angels. Hughes was so obsessed with perfection in the aerial sequences that he waits forever for perfect conditions, right down to cloud formations. The Aviator ends in 1946, when Hughes was still a dashing young man and romancing actresses like Ava Gardner and Katharine Hepburn. This is an astonishingly beautiful and moving movie. The story traces the rise and demise of billionaire Howard Hughes as he struggles to find meaning and purpose in a life unfettered by concerns of money, talent or opportunity. DiCaprio is amazing and Cate Blanchett is incredible as Katherine Hepburn.  This isn't a love story, it's a war story, a war between Howard's unstoppable will, and his fierce inner demons battling for Howard's soul. It is the major relationship and the true heart of the movie, one that fuels his eccentric genius and yet constantly threatens to rip his life apart. He tries to outrun it, building faster and faster airplanes. A great american tragedy.

reviewText: The Aviator is a real surprise. I was expecting another aimless and repetitive Scorsese ramble at best, and was dreading far worse from John Logan's presence as screenwriter (this is the same John Logan who wrote Bats, The Time Machine and Star Trek Nemesis). Instead it turned out to be one of the very best films of the past year, managing to mix and match the epic public aspirations and the private hell of Hughes remarkably successfully. Not just a movie-buff's outing, the darkness is always present (who'd have thought bathrooms could be so terrifying?), always threatening, and the film's final image of Hughes horribly trapped in his obsession is genuinely disturbing. DeCaprio's performance was superb, catching the public face of Hughes so convincingly that he sold the film's interpretation of his private one and serving as a reminder of why he used to be regarded as a great actor before [i]Titanic[/i] turned him into a much reviled icon for the resentful boyfriends of smitten teenage girls. It's impossible to think of another actor of his generation giving such a fearless performance.Excellent supporting performances too, especially Alan Alda, John C. Reilley and, most surprisingly, Kate Beckinsale, who overcomes being physically far too slight for Ava Gardner by capturing her strength surprisingly well. Jude Law made a bit of a pig's ear of Errol Flynn, though: they should have hired Nathanial Parker, who does a pretty neat Errol instead. Fabulous cinematography from Robert Richardson, capturing the evolution of color processes from the relevant eras with real skill and subtlety. And looking at how much more impressive Scorsese's version of the dogfights in Hell's Angels were than the real thing - not to mention that astonishing, almost apocalyptic crash sequence - it's a shame he wasn't around in 1930 to make it for real!

reviewText: Long as it is, 'The Aviator' is never boring.  It has 2h 49 min running time full of dramas, costumes, cameos, flying planes, and the enticing glitter of golden Hollywood.  As many other reviewers have rightly said, DiCaprio shows surprisingly mature acting, and other actors are as wonderful as he is.  But somehow, just somehow I mean, there is a slight feeling that something is wrong with the film.I'm not saying 'The Aviator' is bad.  Its story about the ledendary figure Howard Hughes could never be boring, and how could it be?  Known as the aviator, film director, company owner of TWA, or whatever you name it, Hughes's unique persona never fails to fascinate us.  The film wisely chose the time of his life around the 30s and 40s, when he showed up before the public as celebrity, and before he virtually started to hide himself, living like a hermit.For Hughes, everything must be done with extraordinary scale, and this bio-pic insists on showing it.  From his costly shooting of 'Hell's Angels' to his fights with the authorities, the life of Howard Hughes is always exciting.  That's how the script of John Logan ('Gladiator' and others) shows, but it does not show us any single insight into his eccentric behaviors.  For it's the job of the good actors.Leonard DiCaprio is excellent as Howard Hugh though I think he may look a bit too young at times (when with beard in particular).  Among many supports, which include Ian Holm, Alan Alda, John C. Reilly, Alec Baldwin, Jude Law, Willem Defoe, and Kate Beckinsale, it is Cate Blanchett who is most impressive (and who won Oscar).  Her performance as tomboyish Katharine Hepburn resembles uncannily the real Kate.  Perhaps, I am afraid, too real for some.Lots of CGIs are used for the flight scenes.  In spite of the raving reviews from some professional critics, I am not impressed with these special effects.  Not that they are ineffective.  I'm just saying that they kind of stick out in this Martin Scorsese's film, which I believe is about the human beings like his past films.  Did he need CGIs to make 'Raging Bull'?Martin Scorsese is clearly seeking for something new, leaving his favorite city of New York far behind, and teaming up with DiCaprio, as if forgetting his long-standing collaborations with Robert DeNiro.  But DeNiro also has changed as 'Hide and Seek' shows you, so why not Scorsese?  'The Aviator' is hailed as another masterpiece from the maestro.  Though I admit its merits, I disagree.  It's just the beginning, which might or might not turn out good for him.
summary: Howard Hughes Bio-pic, Uneven But Never Boring

reviewText: THE AVIATOR is a biopic on the life of Howard Hughes. The movie gives a short glimpse into the bizarre, interesting, and uncanny life of Hughes by examining a short portion of his life. The film begins with a naked young Hughes being given a sponge bath by his mother. His mother tells him about different diseases and quizzes the boy on how to spell quarantine.The film then fast forward's about 15 years to the desert set of HELL'S ANGELS. Hughes is making a WWI movie that will end up being one of the most expensive movies ever made (at the time it was the most expensive film ever made; factor in the rate of inflation, HELL'S ANGELS would have cost well over $300,000,000 to make today). Hughes' parents have both died and he now is the sole owner of his father's oil drill bit company. The film briefly examines a 17 year span in Hughes life from the making of HELL'S ANGELS in 1930 until the flight of the Spruce Goose in 1947. Hughes' womanizing (especially his relationship with Katherine Hepburn), his passion for aviation, his idiosyncrasies and obsessive compulsiveness, his fight with Pan Am, and his testimony before Congress are all explored.THE AVIATOR has all the elements of a great movie. Martin Scorsese and crew perfectly captured the glitz, glamour, and glare that was Hollywood in the 1930s and early 1940s. Everything from automobiles to tie tacks have been recreated in detail. Few historical or biopic films have ever captured the essence of a place and time as well as THE AVIATOR does.The acting in the film is superb. Leonardo DiCaprio chose a great follow up to his work in CATCH ME IF YOU CAN and GANGS OF NEW YORK. He does a brilliant job of capturing all the minute and not-so-minute nuances that were a part of Hughes' character. Just as impressive is Cate Blanchett's performance of Katharine Hepburn. This is Blanchett's finest role (in my opinion even surpassing her performance in ELIZABETH) and she should garner an Oscar nomination. The supporting cast is just as fine: everyone from Jude Law playing Errol Flynn to Kate Beckinsale as Eva Gardner to the wonderful John C. Reilly as Noah Dietrich, Hughes' money man.The segment of Hughes' life that is shown is done well, highlighting not only the good (breaking aviation records) but the bad as well (Hughes' mental breakdowns and obsessive compulsive behaviors). A fine balance is struck portraying a very bright, yet confused American figure. I also liked the fact that the movie didn't end in typical Hollywood fashion with Hughes’ victorious flight of the Spruce Goose. The movie builds up to this climatic point that feels so much like a typical Hollywood feel-good ending. But Scorsese delivers this time and continues the action and gives a much more realistic end to the film.With everything it has going for it one would think that THE AVIATOR is a great movie. It should be a great movie. But for some reason it's not. Perhaps the great components were just too volatile to mix together because instead of a great movie worth watching again and again, THE AVIATOR is a film best watched once or twice and that's about it. The film delivers no message and neither is it all that entertaining. The costumes and people are pretty to look at and all the men watch the film wishing they could fly planes as cool looking as the ones Hughes did. But other than that, that's about it. Cate Blanchette is worth watching, but since Hepburn's relationship with Hughes was so short, the energy she brings to the screen quickly departs. DiCaprio does a wonderful job of acting, but Hughes is such a tortured (in spirit and mind) individual that the audience is often left only feeling pity for the man and a desire that someone would come and get Hughes some medicine so he would act normal and do more exciting things. At face value it would seem that THE AVIATOR is a movie that should soar above the clouds. Instead it turns out to be a film that is best left grounded even on a cloudless day.
summary: Lots of Sound and Fury That Signifies a Big Let Down

reviewText: I've always liked DeCaprio in the Aviator, and think it runs a fine line through the life of Howard Hughes, even though I'm not sure how his life turned out after the ending scene in 1947, but more than 2 hours of the movie captures the affects of his accomplishments in a brilliant way, with people telling Hughes stuff like, "Don't put any more money into this movie!" or "Listen to what the Senate has to say and sell TWA to cut our losses." But Hughes never gave up, and the movie is a must-see performance to those who need to be encouraged to keep their own dreams as well.When I placed the order, it took a lengthy amount of time waiting for the movie to finally arrive, but when it did, it was in first-class condition, and the wrapping wasn't even off the cover. Thanks, Amazon!

reviewText: One Man knew the silver screen,money and of course avation. He directed Hell's Angels, he dated Katie Hepburn and invented the Spruce Goose at TWA, he was Howard Hughes. From legendary oscar "NOMINATED" director Martin Scorcesse and starring Leonardo Dicaprio in his most triumphfant and stupendous performance. He portrays the man who built the future. Starring supporting actress winner for this film, Cate Blanchete as the immortal and legendary Katherine Hepburn, starring Kate Beckinsale as Ava Gardner, Alec Baldwin as Juan Tripee, CEO of Pan Am, Gwen Stafani as blonde bombshell Jean Harlow and Jude Law as swashbuckler Errol Flynn. one of the most exciting and brilliant films of the year and mabye the decade, the best Hollywood figure bio since "Chaplin" Leo and Cate are marvelous, Eastwood may own the director oscar, but he doesn't own success as a director. it's an interesting, thrilling gripping life story that truly tells you what you haven't heard. I didn't see Ray, but Leo should have won. Howard Hughes had a huge impact on Hollywood,women and avation and this is his story. If you like Hollywood figure biographies this is the best bio I've seen,but Chaplin comes pretty close. See the romance,the fame and the greatness of the Avatior. reviewText: Much has been made of Martin Scorcese's recreation of heyday Hollywood and his account of American aviation in its infancy. It is much ado about something, something quite grand. The life around which Scorcese has built his long biopic, that of the young billionaire Howard Hughes, before he became an excentric recluse, is less interesting than the times in which he lived. But no matter. This is great fun most of the time, and it contains one of the most exciting plane crashes ever filmed.That crash sequence, brilliantly editied by Thelma Schoonmaker (she won an Oscar, one of five the picture earned) is one of several painstaking set pieces that reveal Scorcese's love of movie craftsmanship. His reputation now rests not so much on his early revelations of urban angst but rather on departures like his "Cape Fear" remake, "The Age of Innocence" and now "The Aviator." The director knows how to walk the mean streets of other landscapes as well.The casting is impeccable save for Leonardo DiCaprio; he's game but does not resemble the brash Hughes in looks, style, voice or authority. Two of the actresses in his life, Katharine Hepburn (Cate Blanchett) and Ava Gardner (Kate Beckinsole), are treated as savvy and compassionate women who tire of his odd behavior. John C. Reily is solid as his steadfast accolyte. There is also fine work from Alec Baldwin, Alan Alda and Willem DaFoe in a brief unbilled appearance.Scorcese increases Hughes' obessive-compulsive behavior in increments that suggest the nutcase he will become after the picture ends. That ending, which intercuts a Senate hearing he dominated with the maiden flight of The Spruce Goose, is fitting and deepened by a sad coda showing Hughes slipping into the psychosis that would isolate him until his death. How many big budget Hollywood epics end like that and still make a lot of money at the box office?

reviewText: Even though he was morally bankrupt, Howard Hughes was an interesting and important figure in aviation history. Martin Scorsese is an equally interesting and important figure to modern filmmaking, and, based upon his films, equally depraved. Despite their spiritual corruption, wouldn't you expect the combination of these two interesting and important figures to produce an interesting - if not important - film? But not so.Visually interesting? Very. The photography is exquisite. Rather than using a traditional sepia tint to give the film that vintage look, the design team uses a sophisticated palette of greens and oranges - the favorite of interior designers - producing a very stunning look. Scorsese's camera eye is as deft as ever, although there are some rather poor cuts in the film. The special effects and recreations of the planes are also exceptional. Most everything shown is real, with very little CGI work. And the period music is nicely balanced.Unfortunately, the drama doesn't follow suit. Almost across the board, recreations of famous people are colorful, yet uninteresting and unconvincing. DiCaprio as Howard Hughes is adequate, but not memorable, as such a legendary - and some would say, heroic - figure requires. He put a lot of research into this part; but I think his desire to fill Hughe's shoes was wishful thinking. He is definitely not the charismatic leader that Howard Hughes probably was, but instead seems weak. For that matter, most of the movie star characters seem artificial. Even Cate Blanchett playing Katherine Hepburn fails to have the wispy, alluring quality that defined Hepburn. Only Alan Alda as Senator Ralph Owen Brewster, who wanted to clip Hughes' wings, and Alec Baldwin as Juan Trippe, the president of competing airline, Pan Am, turn in compelling performances.The story, which should have held everything together, adds little more than a framework for displaying the various vignettes of Hughe's life. Hughes lived a larger life than most men, and that should have come across in the film, but it doesn't. What does come across are his excesses: too much money, too many women, too many toys; and later, too many obsessions, too many compulsions. But what about the character of the man? That, along with the story, seems to have gotten lost in the excesses of the director. Unlike Citizen Kane - which the movie seems to be trying to imitate, and which, unlike this film, did show the inner workings of a driven man - The Aviator simply scratches the surface.As can be expected from any Scorsese film, the audience is left with nothing more to chew on than the paradox of how such brilliance and depravity can coexist in the same man, and of Scorsese in particular. It is almost inconceivable how someone can see so much and understand so little. It is a shame that such talent has been wasted on someone so void of soul and character. Like Hughes, he wallows in the excesses of a life out of control, wrongly thinking that he is somehow blessed above other men. And, like Hughes, he will eventually drive himself mad from his excesses, and reap all the emptiness that such a life deserves.In the DVD's favor, there are more extra features that you can imagine. If you don't learn about the real Howard Hughes from the movie itself, you might get an inkling of what he was like from the features. There are several on Hughes, including a History Channel presentation, and a couple on the disease that he supposedly suffered from: OCD. In addition, almost every department of the production team has its own feature. So, what the film lacks in drama, the features try to make up for. But nothing can make up for Scorsese's - or Hughes' - lack of spiritual consciousness.Waitsel Smith
summary: VISUALLY STUNNING, DRAMATICALLY FLAT AND MORALLY EMPTY

reviewText: Howard Hughes created aviation history, pushed the film industry to new heights and generally excelled at whatever interested him. He flew high on wings of wax. Ultimately, he got a little too close to the sun and as the wings fell apart his anxieties consumed in resulting in Obsessive Compulsive Disorder taking control of his life.  Obsessive compulsive disorder can make an individual feel as if their world is both completely out of control and completely ordered. Someone with OCD requires constant reassurance which is why they are constantly checking the door to see if it is locked, obsessively stacking things, obsessively counting and fight irrational thoughts that threaten their structured existence. It's a symptom of a much larger anxiety. Howard Hughes was a risk taker something that you frequently see in people with OCD but the consequence is a worsening of their OCD symptoms and anxieties. As Hughes fame increased, his need to push the envelope increased and his OCD increasing took control of his life. "The Aviator" is much more than a movie about a man with anxiety and mental illness. Scorsese fashions a film about a man with an endless stream of ideas fighting the demons of mental illness at every turn and, ultimately, losing the battle. Of course we don't see the end of the battle we just experience Hughes in his prime; when we first meet him he's shooting "Hell's Angels" a Hollywood epic that cost the unheard of amount of $4 million in the early 30's. The film revolutionized action films and nearly ruined Hughes. "The Aviator" focuses on the difficulties that Hughes has with his OCD and how it both hampers and pushes his life forward. By the conclusion we see a hint of the Hughes that locked himself in his hotel room in Las Vegas and wore tissue boxes on his feet.Hughes had affairs with actresses (Katherine Hepburn in her Oscar winning role), Ava Gardner (Kate Beckinsale), Terry Wright all the while battling corporate giants that want him to fail; Pam Am's Juan Tripp (Alec Baldwin in a wonderful, oily performance), a corrupt senator (Alan Alda), studio moguls and film censor Breen (Edward Hermann). Stocked with wonderful cameos (Jude Law plays Errol Flynn, "Star Trek: The Next Generation"'s Brent Spiner as plane designer Robert Gross, Ian Holm, Willem DaFoe, singers Rufus, Loudon, and Martha Wainwright, "Six Feet Under" star Frances Conroy) Scorsese's epic tries to make sense of Hughes within the context of how he defined himself (much like "Raging Bull" did). A stylishly directed film, Scorsese pulls out all the stops to make "The Aviator" visually ravishing whether it be his imitation of the Technicolor look for each decade covered or the dazzling juxtaposition ironic images, Scorsese is at the top of his game here. Editor Thelma Schoonmaker provides Scorsese with ample support with her brilliant editing. Although overlooked by Oscar by the more timely "Million Dollar Baby", I have no doubt that time will be much kinder to Scorsese's more ambitious biopic epic. Despite criticism to the contrary, John Logan's fine script may not dig as deeply as some critics like but it's the subtext Scorsese, Logan and DiCaprio provide that may this film much richer than it appears on the surface. While there's outstanding performances from the entire cast, DiCaprio's performance anchors and dominates the film as it should. He brings Hughes to life in the film and his rewarding collaboration with Scorsese continues to be fruitful more so here than in the deeply flawed "Gangs of New York".A beautiful, sharp, vivid transfer receives as much bit space as possible with only the alternate commentary track by director Martin Scorsese with occasional contributions from producer/director Michael Mann and editor Thelma Schooner taking up additional space on the first disc. I'd suggest that film fans keep in mind that the smeared look that you see early on textured surfaces is intentional as the digital master has been grain reduced from start to finish. This was, again, designed to resemble many of the textures seen in early 2 strip Technicolor films. Likewise, you'll notice that the peas on Hughes' plate appear almost turquoise representing the reproduction capabilities of early Technicolor. You'll notice that the color becomes fuller, richer as the film progresses presenting the advancement from early 3 strip to later, mature 3 strip Technicolor. The sound is quite good using the 5.1 Dolby Digital Surround format in a number of subtle but important ways throughout. Dialog and music are crystal clear.This flawed masterpiece is equaled by a great set of extras on disc two. "Making the Aviator" is a standard making of featurette where everybody praises everyone else. There's also a deleted scene where Howard tells Ava about a car accident (although the cut scenes involving Amelia Earhart are not included. Perhaps we'll get this in a deluxe expanded director's edition). The History Channel documentary Howard Hughes focuses much more on the technical innovations he introduced including the changes he made in the world of aviation, satellite technology. Hughes biographer Pat Broeske provides interesting insights as to what occurred in his life that made him the way he was. James Steele author of "Howard Hughes: His life and his Madness" points out how the Hughes empire was build on the oil drilling bit his father designed. Little of the time in the documentary focuses on Hughes movie making. George Marrett author of "Howard Hughes: Aviator" discusses how Hughes and his collaborators broke new ground with air speed records and unique airplane designs."The Role of Howard Hughes in Aviation History" is an original documentary on the achievements that Hughes and his company did to push the envelope of aviation. It's not a conventional biography obviously. We learn from Hughes author George Marrett about Hughes' love of flying. Including interviews with DiCaprio and others associated with the film, it incorporates footage from "The Aviator" but also manages to tell Hughes role in changing air travel and breaking speed records."OCD" focuses on the obsession compulsive disorder that drove him and relieved his anxieties and unstated fears. Actor Leonard DiCaprio discusses the research that he did for the role including contacting OCD expert Dr. Jeffrey Schwartz at the UCLA medical school. OCD is a disorder in the brain where bothersome thoughts intrude into the individuals thoughts without prompting creating fear. The compulsion is the behavior one does again and again to try and control the feeling. There's an interview with someone who has OCD who helped DiCaprio focus the compulsive behavior, the way it's said correctly to help pull it all together. The intrusive thoughts are caused by a chemical balance in the brain. There's also a panel discussion on OCD featuring Scorsese, DiCaprio and Hughes widow Terry Wright."An Evening with Leonardo DiCaprio and Alan Alda" although a promo piece actually provides considerable insight into the characters they played, Hughes and the film itself. DiCaprio discusses how his early interest in the subject brought both Michael Mann and Scorsese on board.Scorsese's animated commentary continues to be a highlight of any DVD he's a part of. When Scorsese slows down a bit Schoonmaker steps in to discuss the editing, the craft of filmmaking and some of the more challenging scenes in the movie. Mann occasionally jumps in. Since he was the director originally attached to this project (he dropped it because he had already made two films based on real people "Ali" and "The Insider" back-to-back and wanted a break) and became a producer his comments are also quite interesting as well particularly about Scorsese uses two color Technicolor, three strip Technicolor and other devices to plant the film firmly in the various decades they took place in.Although it might not be a masterpiece in the same mold as "Raging Bull", "The Aviator" is one of the best films that Scorsese has made in the latter part of his career. Heck, I'd argue that it does belong with his best films; it's just a different sort of film from what most of Scorsese's fans are used to. It has much more in common with "New York, New York" than with "Taxi Driver" although there are also elements of the latter film represented in Hughes obsessive personality. I hate comparing movies but far and away "The Aviator" is a much deeper, richer, ambitious and intelligent film than Clint Eastwood's topical but overrated "Million Dollar Baby". Both films have their merit but the fact that the Academy overlooked this film (as they did Annette Benning for "Being Julia) is a crime and continues to demonstrate how the Academy makes the easy choice when it comes to complex and intelligent filmmaking.
summary: Flying high on wings of wax

reviewText: "The Aviator" depicts Howard Hughes' life from the late 1920s to roughly 1947.  As the movie opens, Hughes (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a newbie film producer - better known in Hollywood circles as a rich Texan oilman (he quickly corrects that his fortune is from manufacturing drill bits, which doesn't augment his credibility).  The film he is making is "Wild Angels," and his obsession with perfectly crafting the planes and flight scenes clearly foreshadows his impending fascination with aviation.  As "The Aviator" unfolds, Hughes has a number of affairs with famous actresses, notably Katherin Hepburn (Cate Blanchett) and Ava Gardner (Kate Beckinsale).  However, his efforts to build innovative aircrafts as well as his takeover and running of TWA comprise the main plot."The Aviator" is fantastic in all technical aspects; it's a gorgeous looking movie.  The film deservedly won Oscars for cinematography, art direction, costume design - pummeling the less flashy Best Picture winner, "Million Dollar Baby."  However, whereas "Million Dollar Baby" was all heart, "The Aviator" is fairly soulless.  I have been a long-time Scorsese fan, and it kills me to say so, but the film is not particularly insightful.  The movie very ably recreates the characters, but it does not deepen our understanding of them.  The script certainly plays up Hughes' likely obsessive-compulsive disorder, which makes for some interesting scenes, but it doesn't humanize him or explain his drive.Despite this flaw, "The Aviator" is still a decent flick.  The acting is generally quite good.  DeCaprio does an admirable job in depicting Hughes' gradual descent; the role made him an Oscar nominee for the first time in 11 years.  In addition, Cate Blanchett won the Supporting Actress Oscar for her portrayal (although her prickly performance is likely to be off-putting for some).  Finally, although "The Aviator" is not as "deep" as one would like, it's rather enjoyable.  For a long film, it moves at a nice clip and features many well constructed and interesting scenes, with Hughes' testimony at a Congressional Hearing on aviation a true highlight.  With Scorsese at the helm, it's difficult to avoid grading "The Aviator" on a curve - it should have been better.  However, it's certainly an above average movie that is likely to appeal to many audiences.
summary: "They should remember him for what he was."

reviewText: First of all, I am not familiar the life story of Howard Hughes, so I am not going to go into detail about his life, because I rather talk about the actors. This is no doubt a big budget period piece filled with airplanes, old Hollywood glamour, and plenty of big stars playing big stars.Leonardo DiCarprio is very impressive as Howard Hughes, the famous director/producer/the aviator/womanizer. I loved his work in What's Eating Gilbert Grape(Johnny Depp), but ever since Titanic, he's kind of "lost it". OK, I did like Marvin's Room and The Basketball Diary. Maybe I just like to see him in indies, not big budgets like Catch Me If You Can. Finally, with this movie, I was very taken by his performance, because it's a very challenging role, and he managed to turn in a multi-layed and intense performance. And he was convincing even when his character aged, considered he's the most boyish looking actor on the "A-list". He's got some chemistry with Cate Blanchett(Katherine Hepburn), but she easily stole most of the scenes with her meticulous mannerism and accent.Although Cate Blanchett only looks 80% alike to Kate Hepburn, she made it up with her performance that was at times delightful and funny. Cate Beckinsale is not very convincing. Let's face it, she doesn't look very much like Ava Gardner, and her performance is weak. It's a miscast. But then we got to give her credit for delivering a memorable line: " How about buying me dinner?"I am not a fan of No Doubt's Gwen Stefani, but I was very eager to see her play the Jene Harlow, the bombshell that came before Marilyn. She looked amazing, and she was at least the eye candy in this film for less than 3 minutes with two or three lines. They should've enlarged her part in this film.As for other supporting roles, Alec Baldwin played rival to Hughes, but he had very little screen time. Jude Law appeared in just one brief scene as Errol Flynn. Willem Dafoe also has just one scene. John C. Reilly had a stroger part as Hughes's assistant.The special effects and visuals were pretty good, especially the airplanes and the sequence of remaking Hell's Angels. I was amazed that Hughes had survived a terrible plane crash, and afterwards, his face was not distorted like Ralph Fiennes in The English Patient. I thought the courtroom scenes were too long and boring, and made the film longer than it should be. It's almost 3 hours.
summary: Leonardo DiCarprio delivered his career best performance!

reviewText: This is by far one of the best movies that Leonardo DiCaprio and Martin Scorsese have done. The world hasn't seen such a great performance by DiCaprio since he was in "The Basketball Diaries" and "What's Eating Gilbert Grape?". He really transformed himself in recent years, even though most people say he's just another pretty boy. Hopefully he'll keep doing extroadinary work like this, and I'm glad to see that he's working with Scorsese! I would never have thought that he would be capable of such a demanding role. He perfectly portrayed Howard Hughes' descent into insanity. He's not one of my favorite actors by any means, but I do think he gives great performances. Thanks to his performance, you could really see how it was possible that such a brilliant business man could be so mentally sick. Even Gwen Stefani's portrayal of Gene Harlow was great (though short). All of the characters were brought to life by the awesome performances and excellent direction by Martin Scorsese seen in this movie.

reviewText: You have to give credit where credits due. "The Aviator" is a fantastic film.  I think it will be more appreciated by film fanatics, it's not what I would call a "popcorn movie".  I enjoyed the cinematography more than anything.  I have never seen a film using the shades of colours they used.  It was enough to wake up the senses.  The acting was phenomenal, Leo was fantabulous as were the rest of the cast.  Cate Blanchett soared as Katheren Hepburn, in some scenes emulating Ms. Pac Man with those outrageous red lips flapping away.  "The Aviator" soared with creativity and good quality film making.  The score, which evokes a deep yet frantic appeal tells the story of a flawed, troubled soul as it unravels into a quary of intense and manic emotions. Martin Scorsese directs another classic film, although overlooked by the Academy (which seems to have cast a blind eye).  R U blind or do u have 20/20 vision, "The Aviator" paints an abstract portrait of someone who had too much and didn't know what to do with it.
